speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us—maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since the beginning of the pandemic, we have taken forceful actions to provide some relief and stability, to ensure that the recovery will be as strong as possible, and to limit lasting damage to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today my colleagues on the Federal Open Market Committee and I made some important changes to our policy statement, including an update to our guidance for the likely path of our policy interest rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Guided by our new Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy that we announced a few weeks ago, these changes clarify our strong commitment over a longer time horizon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Before describing today’s policy actions, let me briefly review recent economic developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Economic activity has picked up from its depressed second-quarter level, when much of the economy was shut down to stem the spread of the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With the reopening of many businesses and factories and fewer people withdrawing from social interactions, household spending looks to have recovered about three-quarters of its earlier decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, spending on services that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality, is still quite weak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The recovery in household spending also likely owes to federal stimulus payments and expanded unemployment benefits, which provided substantial and timely support to household incomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Activity in the housing sector has returned to its level at the beginning of the year, and we are starting to see signs of an improvement in business investment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The recovery has progressed more quickly than generally expected, and forecasts from FOMC participants for economic growth this year have been revised up since our June Summary of September 16, 2020 Economic Projections.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, overall activity remains well below its level before the Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL pandemic and the path ahead remains highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the labor market, roughly half of the 22 million jobs that were lost in March and April have been regained as many people returned to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate declined over the past four months but remains elevated at 8.4 percent as of August.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Although we welcome this progress, we will not lose sight of the millions of Americans who remain out of work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, FOMC participants project the unemployment rate to continue to decline; the median projection is 7.6 percent at the end of this year, 5.5 percent next year, and 4 percent by 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, the high level of joblessness has been especially severe for lower-wage workers in the services sector, for women, and for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic dislocation has upended many lives and created great uncertainty about the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The pandemic has also left a significant imprint on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For some goods, including food, supply constraints have led to notably higher prices, adding to the burden for those struggling with lost income.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: More broadly, however, weaker demand, especially in sectors that have been most affected by the pandemic, has held down consumer prices, and overall, inflation is running well below our 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median inflation projection from FOMC participants rises from 1.2 percent this year to 1.7 percent next year and reaches 2 percent in 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the economy began its recovery, COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths also rose.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The reimposition of some social-distancing restrictions as well as more cautious behavior by many individuals have succeeded in slowing the spread of the virus.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we have emphasized September 16, 2020 throughout the pandemic, the outlook for the economy is extraordinarily uncertain and will Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL depend in large part on our success in keeping the virus in check.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of us have a role to play in our nation’s response to the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following the advice of public health professionals to keep appropriate social distances and to wear masks in public will help get the economy back to full strength.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A full economic recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it is safe to reengage in a broad range of activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The path forward will also depend on the policy actions taken across all parts of the government to provide relief and to support the recovery for as long as needed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Federal Reserve’s response to this crisis has been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We remain committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy in this challenging time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The changes we made in today’s policy statement reflect our strategy to achieve our dual-mandate goals by seeking to eliminate shortfalls from maximum employment and achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time, as we articulated in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We view maximum employment as a broad-based and inclusive goal and do not see a high level of employment as posing a policy concern unless accompanied by signs of unwanted increases in inflation or the emergence of other risks that could impede the attainment of our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we believe that achieving inflation that averages 2 percent over time helps ensure that longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at our longer-run 2 percent objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In turn, well-anchored inflation expectations enhance our ability to meet both our employment and inflation objectives, particularly in the new normal in which interest rates are closer to their effective lower bound even in good times.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Hence, as we say in our statement, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we “will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.” We expect “to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these outcomes”—including maximum employment—“are achieved.” With regard to interest rates, we now indicate that we expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate “until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessments of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.” In addition, over coming months we will continue to increase our “holdings of Treasury securities and agency mortgage-backed securities at least at the current pace.” These asset purchases are intended “to sustain smooth market functioning and help foster accommodative financial conditions, thereby supporting the flow of credit to households and businesses.” We believe the strong policy guidance we are providing today will serve the economy well by promoting our goals through the many possible paths the recovery may take.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, as we note in our policy statement, we “would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate if risks emerge that could impede the attainment of our [the Committee’s] goals.” The Federal Reserve has also been taking broad and forceful actions to more directly support the flow of credit in the economy for households, for businesses large and small, and for state and local governments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Preserving the flow of credit is essential for mitigating the damage to the economy and promoting a robust recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many of our programs rely on emergency lending powers that require the support of the Treasury Department and are available only in September 16, 2020 very unusual circumstances, such as those we find ourselves in today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These programs serve as a Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL backstop to key credit markets and appear to have restored the flow of credit from private lenders through normal channels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have deployed these lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled, in large part, by financial backing and support from Congress and the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When the time comes, after the crisis has passed, we will put these emergency tools back in the toolbox.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I have emphasized before, these are lending powers, not spending powers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed cannot grant money to particular beneficiaries.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can only create programs or facilities with broad-based eligibility to make loans to solvent entities with the expectation that the loans will be repaid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many borrowers are benefiting from these programs, as is the overall economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But for many others, getting a loan that may be difficult to repay may not be the answer.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In these cases, direct fiscal support may be needed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Elected officials have the power to tax and spend and to make decisions about where we, as a society, should direct our collective resources.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The fiscal policy actions that have been taken thus far have made a critical difference to families, businesses, and communities across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even so, the current economic downturn is the most severe in our lifetimes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will take a while to get back to the levels of economic activity and employment that prevailed at the beginning of this year, and it may take continued support from both monetary and fiscal policy to achieve that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help assure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Finally, I would like to take a moment to recognize the passing of our friend and colleague, Thomas Laubach.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: His outstanding analysis and advice have been indispensable to the FOMC and have played a key role in the policy decisions that will define this era of the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: He will be remembered for his intellect, but also his kindness, his equanimity, and his dedication to achieving our mission on behalf of the American people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will miss him.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll now be glad to take your questions.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nick Timiraos.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Good afternoon, Chair Powell.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos from the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: You’ve been very clear about the Committee’s intention on rates, not even thinking about thinking about raising rates, and today showing low rates even as unemployment falls to 4 percent and inflation rises to 2 percent.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: My question is about asset purchases.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Does the guidance today apply to the current asset purchase pace?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Are there any macroeconomic conditions under which you would favor increasing the monthly pace of Treasury and MBS purchases?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And under what conditions would a decrease in the monthly pace of purchases be appropriate?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we say in our postmeeting statement that we’ll continue to increase our securities holdings “at least at the current pace” over coming months “to sustain smooth market functioning and help foster accommodative financial conditions.” That latter part is an updating of our guidance to reflect what I’ve been saying in these press conferences for some time and what other central banks have acknowledged, which is that the purchases are fostering accommodative financial conditions as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That amounts to roughly $80 billion a month of Treasuries and $40 billion net per month for MBS.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do—we do think that these purchases have been effective in, in restoring orderly market conditions and have supported the flow of credit to households and businesses, including by fostering more accommodative financial conditions, which, of course, we think is a good thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in terms of going forward, I would just say this: There are various ways and margins that we can adjust our tools going forward, and we’ll continue to monitor developments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re prepared to adjust our plans as appropriate.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: If I could—if I could follow up, I suppose the question I have is, why give guidance on one policy tool but not give guidance on the other policy tool when the Fed has talked about those two policy tools working together?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we think our—we think our policy stance is appropriate today, and we’re prepared to adjust it going forward as we, as we see appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And today we believe that particularly this very strong forward guidance—very powerful forward guidance that we’ve announced today will provide strong support for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Effectively, we’re saying that rates will remain highly accommodative until the economy is far along in its recovery, and that, that should be a very powerful statement in supporting economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now we’re buying $120 billion in securities per month across the—across the Treasury curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s also adding to accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do have the flexibility to adjust that tool and, and the rate tool and, and other tools as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But as for right now, we think—we think that our policy setting is appropriate to support the expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We did—we said from the beginning that we would first try to provide some support and stability and relief in the first phase of the crisis, the acute phase, and then we would support the expansion when it came.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, it’s here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s well along.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so that’s why we changed our guidance today, and we do have the flexibility to do more when we think it’s appropriate.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Jeanna.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Thanks for taking my question.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Jeanna Smialek, New York Times.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: I was wondering, you beefed up your language on financial stability in the long-run statement that you unveiled with your Jackson Hole speech last month.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: I’m wondering if you could kind of walk us through how you think about financial stability concerns as a factor in guiding and interpreting increases.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: You know, would financial stability concerns on their own be enough to merit changes in the fed funds rate?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Or would they have to come in conjunction with an overheating on inflation or some sort of dramatic drop in the unemployment rate?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: If you could, sort of, give us an outline of your thinking there, please.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what we said in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy was that the Committee’s policy decisions reflect “its longer-run goals, its medium-term outlook, and its assessment[s] of the balance of risks, including risks to the financial system that could impede the attainment of the Committee’s goals.” So that’s what we said about financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And today we said that we’d “be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate if risks emerge that could impede the attainment of our [the Committee’s] goals.” But you asked specifically about, about financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One thing I would say is that financial—that monetary policy should not be the first line of defense—is not the first line of defense on financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We look to more appropriate tools in the first instance as a first line of defense, and those would be regulation, supervision, high capital, high liquidity, stress testing—all of those things, macroprudential tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of those things are, are really the first line of defense on financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we always leave open the idea that we will not ignore September 16, 2020 those kinds of risks and other kinds of risks, more broadly, that could impede the attainment of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL our goals in, in setting monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s really how we think about it, but principally that, you know, other tools are the—are the frontline, as I mentioned.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Just to follow up quickly, if, if other tools aren’t forthcoming, would financial stability concerns in and of themselves be enough to warrant a rate hike?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, what we said again in the [Statement on] Longer-Run [Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy]—you know, in our consensus statement is that we, you know—“policy decisions reflect … the balance of risks, including risks to the financial system that could impede the attainment of the Committee’s goals.” So the test would be, you know, does a majority of the Committee feel that, that monetary policy is, is triggering that?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, that would be—that would be the test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s not something that we’ve done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do monitor financial stability concerns, of course, intensely and regularly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We try to use our other tools on them, but we, we do keep them in mind as we think about monetary policy.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Steve Liesman.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, I wonder if you could help me understand how the projections of the Committee line up with the goals of the Committee.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: You’ve now altered the projections to—the statement to aim for inflation above 2 percent.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: But when I look at the SEP, I don’t see the Committee believing a single year in the next four years that you are ever above 2 percent.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: In fact, for each year, you are below it until 2023, which is the first time that you actually hit 2 percent.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: So do you think—are, are you confident—is this just the Committee is not confident that not only can it not hit its 2 percent goal, but that now it can’t hit its goal of being above 2 percent?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, you don’t—you also don’t see people, by and large, lifting off or raising interest rates above zero.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess there are 4 exceptions out of a Committee of 17 during that—during the forecast period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we don’t reach 2 percent, but we get very close to it in the forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We reach 2 percent—I guess the median is 2 percent at the end of 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, you know what the guidance says.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It says that we expect that the current setting of, of our rates will be—what we expect [is] that it will be appropriate until such time as we reach 2 percent inflation, that we feel that labor market conditions are consistent with our assessment of maximum employment, and that we’re on track to achieve inflation moderate—inflation moderately above.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s the test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t think there’s any conflict between those two because, you know, the, the way they’re set up, the projections don’t show the out years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You asked about confidence, and I would say that this, this very strong, very powerful guidance shows both our confidence and our determination.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It shows our confidence that we can reach this goal and our determination to do so.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I’m sorry, if I could just follow up without being simplistic about this.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: But why wouldn’t—if the Committee was confident that it could reach its new goal of aiming for inflation above 2 percent, why wouldn’t one of those years at least show inflation being above 2 percent on the median forecast?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Because it—we think, looking at everything we know about inflation dynamics in the United States and around the world over recent decades, we expect it will take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect that the economy will recover quickly now, but that that pace will slow as, as people go back to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll still have an area of the economy—a big area of the economy—that struggles.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There will be slack in the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy will be below September 16, 2020 maximum employment, below full demand.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that will tend to wear—to put downward Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL pressure on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think that once we get up closer to maximum employment, we think that inflation will come back, generally.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, I mean, that’s sort of what happened during the last long expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a slow process, but—but there is a process there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation does move up over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do expect that will continue today, and we expect that our, our guidance is powerful and will help that outcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that—that effectively saying that policy will remain highly accommodative until the economy is very far along in its recovery should provide strong support for the economy and get us there sooner rather than later.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Rachel Siegel.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thanks very much for taking my question.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: I wanted to ask if you anticipate a slowing in the pace of the recovery if there is not another stimulus package and, specifically, if there are particular holes still remaining in the economy that you think could be helped by more aid from Congress.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thanks very much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, first, if you look at the Summary of Economic Projections that my colleagues and I filed for this meeting, what you’ll see is an expectation that the recovery will continue—that it will continue at a reasonable pace through 2021, ’22, and ’23.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do expect that that pace will slow just because you would expect that the, the pace would be fastest right at the beginning of the—right at the beginning of the recovery, because you had such a sharp decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You would expect that the third quarter should be the fastest gains, and that, after that, the pace should slow down to a more normal pace.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do expect that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of fiscal policy—you asked about fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, one thing—I guess I would start by saying that the initial response from fiscal authorities was rapid.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was September 16, 2020 forceful and pretty effective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re seeing the results of that in—today in income and Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL household spending data, in the labor market data, in the construction data, in the data for business equipment spending, and the fact that businesses are staying in business, and, you know, the pace of default and things like that has really slowed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s been a really positive effect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That said, my sense is that more fiscal support is likely to be needed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, the details of that are for Congress, not for the Fed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would just say, there are still roughly 11 million people still out of work due to the pandemic, and a good part of those people were working in industries that are likely to struggle.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those people may need additional, additional support as they try to find their way through what will be a difficult time for them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve also got struggling small businesses, especially those in the business of facing directly to the public.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have state and local governments dealing with a drop in revenue at the same time spending has gone up, much of it related to the pandemic and economic effects.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, again, I would say, the fiscal support has been essential in, in the good progress we see now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, finally, I’ll note that just about all—the overwhelming majority of, of private forecasters who, who project an ongoing recovery are assuming there will be substantial additional fiscal support.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Mike Derby.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: [Inaudible] taking my question.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Should we expect any further evolutions in forward guidance, say, maybe an adoption of something akin to the Evans rule that we had a few years ago?

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Or is there something else that the Fed might be considering in the future?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, so we think that the forward guidance we adopted today is appropriate and, as I mentioned, powerful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Effectively, what it says is that we’ll, we will keep policy where it is now—keep the rate policy where it is now until unemployment reaches the Committee’s assessments or levels that are—sorry, not unemployment, labor market conditions reach levels that are consistent with the Committee’s assessments of maximum employment, until inflation reaches 2 percent, and until it’s on track to go above 2 percent moderately for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s very strong forward guidance, and we think that that will be durable guidance that will provide significant support to the economy in coming years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s really our thinking on, on forward guidance on rates.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Howard Schneider.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thanks, Chair Powell, for doing this.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: So to follow up on Mike’s question there, since you described this guidance as durable, you—you’ve set up a three-part test here for rate hikes: levels consistent with assessments of maximum employment, inflation has risen to 2 percent, and you’re on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Each of these have modifiers, and I wonder if you could explain them a little bit more.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: How do we pin down assessments of maximum employment?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: When you say that “inflation has risen to 2 percent,” does that mean 2 percent for a day, a month, six months?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: And when you say “on track to moderately exceed,” how should we define “moderately”?

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: And how should we define “for some time”?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you know, maximum employment is not—is not something that can be reduced to a number the way inflation can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a broad range of factors.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It really always has been and, really, a substantial number of factors that we’ve indicated we would look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s broader labor conditions, consistent with our Committee’s assessment of maximum September 16, 2020 employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that would certainly mean low unemployment, it would mean high labor force Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL participation, it would mean wages—it would be a whole range of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re not looking at a rule.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re looking at a judgmental assessment, which I think we’ll be very transparent about as we—as we go forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of inflation, you know, this is a Committee that is both confident and committed to—and determined to reach our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the idea that we would look for the, the quickest way out is just—it’s just not who we are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not that—there’s no message of that here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would not be looking for one month of 2 percent inflation; we said return to 2—to achieve 2 percent inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So just understand that, you know, we’re strongly committed to achieving our goals and the overshoot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that should tell you about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Oh, in terms of—okay, in terms of—so, what does “moderate” mean?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It means not large.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It doesn’t—it means not very high above 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It means moderate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that’s a fairly well-understood word.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of—in terms of “for a time,” what it means is not permanently and not for a sustained period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’re, we’re resisting the urge to try to create some sort of a rule or a formula here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think the, the public will understand pretty well what we want.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s actually pretty straightforward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want to achieve inflation that averages 2 percent over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if we do that, inflation expectations will be right at 2 percent, and that’ll help us achieve 2 percent inflation over time and avoid the situation where the central bank loses its ability to support the economy.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: James Politi.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: Thanks for taking the question.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: James Politi with the Financial Times.

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: Do you consider today’s enhanced forward guidance to have actual accommodation to the—to the U.S. economy from a monetary perspective and sort of deliver further support for the September 16, 2020 economy?

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: Or is it just a tweak to your existing policy stance?

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: And, in terms of fiscal support, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL do you assume in your own projections—not just, you know, private forecasters—that additional fiscal support will be forthcoming?

speaker: JAMES POLITI
sentence: Or do you expect weaker growth or a—or a larger contraction rather this year if no fiscal support is forthcoming?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, in terms of the effects, so I think what we’ve done is—is more or less aligned with the consensus statement today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s, it’s in line with what, what might have been expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, I think over time it will provide very powerful support for this economy as we move forward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In a sense, it’s consistent with expectations, so I don’t—I’m not looking for a big reaction right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I think, over time, again, guidance that we expect to retain the current stance until the economy is—has moved very far toward our goals is a strong and powerful thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that will be supportive of the economy over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of additional fiscal support, I guess your question is, what would happen if—yes, so, people have different assessments, and, and different participants in the FOMC made different assessments on their own.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think broadly, though, there is an expectation among private forecasters and among FOMC participants that there will be some further fiscal action.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there does seem to be an appetite on the part of all the relevant players to doing something.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The question is, how much and when?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so I would just say that if—and it’s very hard to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, so far the economy has proven resilient to the—to the lapsing of the—to the, of the CARES Act unemployment—enhanced unemployment benefits.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there’s, there’s certainly a risk, though, that, that those who are unemployed have saved—appear to have saved some of those benefits, and they’ll, they’ll now spend them, and that, as the months pass, if, if there’s no follow-up on that, if there isn’t additional support and there isn’t a job for the—some of those people who are, are from September 16, 2020 industries where, where it’s going to be very hard to find new work, then you’ll—that will start Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL to show up in economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll also show up in things like evictions and foreclosures and, and, you know, things that will scar and damage the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s a downside risk.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I think the real question is, is, when and how much and what will be the—what will be the contents?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, no one—no one has any certainty around that, but, broadly speaking, if we don’t get that, then there would certainly be downside risks through the—certainly through the channel I mentioned.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Anneken, CNN.

speaker: ANNEKEN TAPPE
sentence: Thanks for taking my question.

speaker: ANNEKEN TAPPE
sentence: Chairman Powell, given the recent update to the policy framework and repeated calls for this in the Fed Listens events, is the Fed open to other measures of the economy, such as income inequality and affordability of housing?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we—you know, we monitor everything we think is important in the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in that—in a broad sense, all of it goes into thinking about monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You mentioned inequality.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, disparities in, in income and in financial well-being by various demographic and racial categories is something we monitor carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inequality, which I would point to—it’s a multifaceted thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would point to the relative stagnation of incomes for people at the lower end of the income spectrum and also lower mobility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those are things that hold back our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The thing is, we don’t really have the tools to address those.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we have interest rates and bank supervision and financial stability policy and things like that, but we can’t—we can’t get at those things through our tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When we lower the federal funds rate, that supports the economy across a broad range of, of people and activities, but we can’t—we don’t have the ability to target particular groups.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Notwithstanding that, we, we do talk about it, because these are important features of our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we—you know, I, I think those are—those distributional issues are, are issues that are really for our elected officials.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would say, I take them seriously as holding back our economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The productive capacity of the economy is limited when not everyone has the opportunity, has the educational background and, and the health care and all the things that you need to be an active participant in our workforce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we can—if we want to have the, the highest potential output and the—and the best output for our economy, we need that prosperity to be very broadly spread in the longer run.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I—again, I would just say, the Fed—you know, we can talk about those things a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in, in—when we think about maximum employment in particular, we do look at individual groups.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So high unemployment in a particular racial group like African Americans when—you know, we would look at that as we think about whether we’re really at maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would look—we would look at that along with a lot of other data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the answer is, we do look at all those things and, and do what we can with our tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, ultimately, these are issues for elected representatives.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Edward Lawrence.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Yes, thank you, Chairman Powell, for the question.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: I just wanted some clarity here.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: At what point do you think it’s prudent to shift the bond purchases from market stability—as you had said, from the shorter-term maturities to more longer-term, more stimulus-related?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we think our—we think that our asset purchases are doing both the thing—both those things today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think, clearly, there’s been great progress, in terms of market function.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you remember, early in the spring when the acute phase of the September 16, 2020 pandemic hit, market function was very low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s improved rapidly and, and in many Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL respects is, is in a good place now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also, though, think that these asset purchases, which total $120 billion a month—you know, which is much larger than, for example, the last asset purchase program during the Global Financial Crisis and the recovery therefrom—we think that that’s also providing accommodative financial conditions and supporting growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we think that’s fine.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re also aware that we, we—there are ways we can adjust that, you know, to do various things—you know, make it smaller, make it larger, and also target different sectors of the—of the curve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’re, we’re going to continue to monitor developments, and we’re prepared to adjust our plans as appropriate.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Victoria.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Victoria Guida.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Thanks for taking my question.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: I wanted to ask about a couple of things.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: First of all, if we don’t get a vaccine until well into next year, what does that mean for the economy?

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And then, somewhat related, I was wondering if you could provide any more detail about the stress scenarios that you all are going to release for the big banks and whether that is going to be another full-blown stress test, whether we’re going to publicly see those results, and what it might mean for bank payouts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Great.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on the first one, what’s happening is basically we’re learning to live with—right now, we're learning to live with COVID, which still spreads.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re learning to, to engage in economic activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All of this recovery that we’ve seen is in a context where—you know, where people are still at risk of, of catching it, and yet we’re able to resume lots and lots of economic activities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that involves, as I mentioned, you know—I think the more social distancing we can preserve as we go back into the workforce—wearing masks, keeping our distance, that kind of thing—the better we’ll be able to get economic activity September 16, 2020 back up close to where it was.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I do think, though, there are areas of the economy that are just Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL going to really struggle until we have an—a vaccine that’s, that’s in wide—you know, wide usage and is, is widely trusted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And those are the ones where people were getting really closely—close together.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I also think testing—to the extent you have cheap and rapid testing, you can do a lot with that in the workforce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can—you can build confidence in the workforce if you have regular—very regular testing that doesn’t cost very much and you get the results really quickly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you do that, you’ll be able to open a lot of workforces, particularly in cities where the overall case numbers are quite low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that will help a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we’re, we’re going to be finding lots and lots of ways to get out towards—you know, as far as we can.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s always going to be that—for, for some time, there’s going to be certain activities that will be—that will be hard to, to resume.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I think that’s the only way I can say it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think trying to—you know, we all—when we make a forecast, we make assessments about that, but it’s really hard to say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is no template here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no—you know, there’s no experience with this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, frankly, for the last 60 days or so, the economy’s recovered faster than expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that may continue or not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We just don’t know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we should do those things that we control to make sure that we can recover as quickly as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the main thing, again, is wearing a mask and keeping your distance while you’re in the workforce.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s something we can all do that will limit the spread and let people go back to work, avoid major outbreaks, and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In, in terms of the stress tests, so I really don’t have any—you know, we’re getting ready quite soon to be making announcements and saying things publicly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s not much I can say with you—nothing, really, that I can say that’s—on that today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t have anything for you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Chris Condon.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Thank you, Michelle.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Good afternoon, Chairman Powell.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: You have emphasized many times, including today, that the Fed can only lend and not spend, and sometimes the latter is what’s really needed.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: But to the extent that a $600 billion lending program for small and midsize companies could help, what exactly is wrong with the design or function of the Main Street Lending Program, which has purchased just, I think, $1.4 billion in loans so far?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Eric Rosengren at the Boston Fed has said recently that Congress should clarify how much risk it wants the program to take.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: But Congress has already appropriated substantial funds for the 13(3) programs, and these are funds that are explicitly designed to absorb losses.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Meanwhile, my colleagues who cover the banking sector say they’re being told by commercial banks that the Treasury Department is advising them to target zero losses—zero losses in Main Street Program loans.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: So, if I may, why is it that the Federal Reserve, the Congress, and the Treasury apparently cannot agree on a loss tolerance that should be applied to the Main Street Lending Program in a way that would allow badly needed credit to reach these companies?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, a couple things about Main Street.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It, it reaches the whole nation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s got more than half of the banking industry assets signed up among the banks that are part of it, and it’s making loans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The number is more like—it’s close to $2 billion now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the numbers are going up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Banks are joining; borrowers are coming.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s significant.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s September 16, 2020 relatively small now, but it can scale up in response to economic conditions, should that be— Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL should that be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, if you look out in the lending world, surveys generally find that, that firms are not citing credit constraints as a top problem.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, that is a lot of PPP, bank credit lines, and syndicated loans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a lot of credit being let out there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but you’re right.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we are looking at some things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re looking at—some lenders are concerned about the underwriting expectations.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So banks are going to—their approach is likely to be that they’re going to underwrite this loan roughly the same as they underwrite any loan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re keeping part of it, and, you know, what, what we want to do is make sure that—that they know that they should take the payment deferrals and other things in, in place, and also that—you know, it’s, it’s really—it’s really a, a facility for, for companies or borrowers that, that don’t have access to, to “regular way” borrowing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Otherwise, why would we need Main Street?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s what we're working on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll be doing some, some—we’ll be making some changes in that respect.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t—I saw what President Rosengren said.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I can’t really comment directly on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I just would say that, you know, this is 13(3).

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the law under section 13(3), it’s very clear that we are to make loans only to solvent borrowers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and the CARES Act is quite specific in keeping all of the terms of, of section 13(3) in effect, including the requirement that we, you know, gather good evidence that the borrower is solvent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This was—this law was amended in, you know, under—in Dodd-Frank, and the idea was, was to make it challenging and put hurdles in place before we made loans—at the time, the thinking was to banks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So now we—now we’re using that same law for, for smaller business borrowers, and, you know, it doesn’t—it’s not a perfect fit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, I would also just say, for many borrowers, September 16, 2020 they’re in a situation where their business is still relatively shut down, and they won’t be able to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL service a loan, and so they may need more fiscal support.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Having said that, we’re, we’re continuing to work to, to improve Main Street, to make it more broadly available—make it pretty much to any company that needs it and that can service a loan.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: And can you just very briefly address the reports that the Treasury is advising banks to target zero losses?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER CONDON
sentence: Is that appropriate?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I can’t say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t—I don’t know about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I haven’t heard those reports.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, again, if you think about it, we, we weren’t—we’re, we’re going to have to go through the banking system to do this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—we’re not going to have a hundred thousand or a million loan officers working for the Fed and the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re going to go through the banking system, and the banks—banks like to make good loans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what they do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re trained to make good loans.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you should expect that they—and we expect that they will do some underwriting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also want them to take some risk, obviously, because that was the point of it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the question is, how do you dial that in?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s not an easy thing to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’re getting some loans made, and we’re hopeful that we’ll, that we’ll clarify this and that credit will continue to flow.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Chris Rugaber.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Hi, thanks for taking my question.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Chair Powell, you’ve talked a couple of times about parts of the economy that may not recover as fast as we’ve seen so far.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Presumably you’re referring to airlines, hotels, other sections—you know, parts of the economy that rely on close contact.

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: How are you thinking about that, in terms of its overall impact?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Is that sector large enough to say keep unemployment above—you know, far above your maximum goals?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Are you expecting that to come back with a vaccine?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Or are a lot of September 16, 2020 those folks going to have to find, you know, new jobs in new industries?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: And should we expect Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL the Fed will keep rates at zero until all of that reallocation is done?

speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, we—of course, we can’t be—we can’t be really sure we know the answers to those questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say, the, the likely path is that the—that the expansion will continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s, as I said, it’s well along, and it’ll move most easily through the parts of the economy—it’ll still take some time, but the parts of the economy that weren’t exactly directly affected, that didn’t involve getting people in large groups together to feed them, to fly them around, to put them in hotels, do entertainment, things like that—those are going to be the places that are—that are very challenging.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there will also be the—you know, the places that are affected that way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s going to be challenging for, for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t really know how long that will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s—you know, it’s millions of people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, we had 11 million—something like 11 million people in the payroll survey have gone back to work out of 22 million who went—who lost their jobs in March and April.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s half of them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, 11 million—particularly if the pace of, of returning to work slows down, it’s going to leave a large—a large group of people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’ll be very meaningful from a macroeconomic standpoint.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And our commitment is not to forget those people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, we want—you know, the sense of our forward guidance is that policy will remain, as we’ve said, highly accommodative until the—until the expansion is well along—really, very close to our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And even after, if we do lift off, we will keep policy accommodative until we actually have a moderate overshoot of inflation for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those are powerful commitments that we think will, will support the full recovery, including those people, as long as it takes.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

sentence: Mike McKee.

sentence: Not at all.

sentence: We think it’s powerful.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, as I mentioned, you know, this is the kind of guidance that will provide support for the economy over time, the idea being that policy will remain highly accommodative until the recovery is well along—really, very close to our goals—and then will remain accommodative even after we lift off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think that’s, that’s a really strong place for, for rate policy to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, again, we have the other margins that we can still use.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Certainly, we’re not out of ammo.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Well, if I could follow up, in terms of the balance sheet, are you concerned that your actions are more likely to produce asset price inflation than goods-and-services inflation?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: In other words, are you risking a bubble on Wall Street?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, so, of course we monitor financial conditions very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are—these are not new questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These were questions that were very much in the air a decade ago and more when, when the Fed first started doing QE.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, I would say, if you look at the long experience of, you know, the 10-year, 8-month expansion, the longest in our September 16, 2020 recorded history, it included an awful lot of quantitative easing and low rates for 7 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, I Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL would say, it was notable for the lack of the emergence of, of some sort of a financial bubble—a housing bubble or some kind of a bubble, the popping of which could threaten the expansion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That didn’t happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, frankly, it hasn’t really happened around the world since then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That doesn’t mean that it won’t happen, but—and so, of course, it’s something that we monitor carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: After the financial crisis, we started a new—a whole division of the Fed to focus on financial stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We look at it in every—from every perspective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The FOMC gets briefed on a quarterly basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Board here, we talk about it more or less on an ongoing basis, so it is something we monitor.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I don’t know that the—that the connection between asset purchases and, and financial stability is a particularly tight one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but again, we won’t be—we won’t be just assuming that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll be checking carefully as we go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, the kinds of tools that we would use to address those sorts of things are not really monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would be more tools that strengthen the financial system.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Don Lee.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: Chair Powell, I’d like to ask you about the labor market.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: As you know, in August there were about 30 million persons claiming unemployment benefits.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: Yet the BLS jobs report for August showed about 13½ million unemployed, only about 6 million more than before the pandemic.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: I wonder how you reconcile that and what you think the actual labor market conditions are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I mean, I think the overall picture—take a step back from this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The overall picture is clear, and that is that the labor market has been recovering, but that it’s a long way—a long way from maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that’s, that’s the bottom line on it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: September 16, 2020 So, within that, though—take claims in particular.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The number of claims, the quantity of claims, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and, frankly, the fact that PUA claims are new—the Pandemic Unemployment Assistance claims—that’s a new system that had to be set up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The actual counting of the claims is, is volatile, and, and it’s very difficult to take much signal about the particular level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, because people were setting those systems up, and when they got them set up, they counted them all at once and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think, though, what you’ve seen is that the level of—certainly the level of initial claims has declined very sharply from the very high levels of March and April and is now at a lower level—continues either to be flat or gradually decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s worth noting—and that’s good—it’s worth noting that that level is maybe five times the level of what claims were.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Claims were around 200,000; now they’re 900,000, in that range, weekly for, for initial claims.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that just tells you, the labor market has improved, but it’s a long, long way from maximum employment, and it will be some time getting back there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that’s the best way to think about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In many parts of the economy there’s just a lot of disruption, and it’s, it’s really hard to say precisely where we are.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’ll give you another example with—you know, we say unemployment’s 8.4 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But if you count those who are—who are misidentified as, as employed when they’re actually unemployed and you add back some part of the participation number—so if you were—if you had a job and you were in the labor force in February and you lost it because of the pandemic, some of you are now being reported as out of the labor force.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I—you know, I would—I would more look at those people as unemployed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you add those back, the level of unemployment’s probably 3 percent higher.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: On the other hand, by that metric, the, the September 16, 2020 unemployment rate would have been in the—in the 20s in, in April.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the improvement has Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL been quite substantial under any measurement.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the level is still quite high.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: Well, if I could follow up, is—is it the Fed’s aim to get back to 3.5 percent or even lower?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Yes, absolutely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I, I can’t be precise about a particular number, but let me just say, there was a lot to like about 3½ percent unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not a magic number.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No one would say that number is the touchstone or that is, you know, maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would just say, you asked about 3½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: A 3½ percent unemployment rate showed, you know, gains being shared very widely across the income spectrum—in fact, going more to people at the bottom end of the spectrum.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It showed labor force participation coming up as—up above many estimates of its trend, as people who’d been out of the labor force were being pulled into a tight job market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a lot to like about a tough—a tight job market, particularly in a world where we didn’t see inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, yes, we’d love to get back to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I would say, we would like to get back—rather than to a particular number, we’d like to get back to a strong labor market where wages are moving up, where people can find work, where labor force participation is holding up nicely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’d really love to get back to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, of course we would—we need inflation to perform in line with, with our framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But the good news is, we think we can have quite low unemployment without raising troubling inflation.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Nancy Marshall-Genzer.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Hi, Nancy Marshall-Genzer with Marketplace.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: Chair Powell, I want to follow up on the wealth gap issue.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: I know you were—that you have limited September 16, 2020 tools.

speaker: NANCY MARSHALL-GENZER
sentence: But are there things that you can do, possibly in the area of research and maybe expand Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL your research on racial economic gaps?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we do—we are gifted with a, a substantial group of researchers who really cover the waterfront.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do a significant amount of research on racial disparities in—across multiple variables, including wealth, as you asked about.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we also—remember, we have our Division of Consumer and Community Affairs, which is present in communities around the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the Reserve Banks all have very active community affairs groups.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re present in communities around the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it wasn’t just the Fed—Fed Listens events.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s more, just, over a long period of time we, we are in contact with people in those communities to understand their experience of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We serve all Americans, and we know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to use our tools to, to reflect that fact.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the answer is “yes.” We do quite a bit of research, and I suppose we could do more, but we really do a lot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we contribute to those fields and those assessments of, of the state of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we do that not just because it’s interesting and important, but because it’s important for the economy and important for our mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are assigned “maximum employment.” Now, what does that mean?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned earlier, it doesn’t mean a particular headline unemployment number.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What it means is maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we look at—look at that in many, many different variables, and we ask ourselves whether those variables are—those labor market conditions are consistent with our assessments of what would constitute maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that would include all of the things that we’re talking about.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Greg Robb.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Hi, Greg Robb from MarketWatch.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thanks for this.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I want to go back to the new forward guidance that you have.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And you said that it’s powerful, but you’ve already have two dissent—two dissenting voters on it.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And I was wondering if there’s other, other people who argued against it.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And what do you say to the two who dissented?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: It looks like President Kashkari wanted a simpler forward guidance, and President Kaplan thought that the current guidance you have was fine for now.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: So, like, how did you argue back on those, on those arguments?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t—I don’t want to comment particularly on, on the two dissenters, but they, they consent—they dissented from, of course, different perspectives, and, and that should be clear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s their—they’re not—they’re sort of on, on two sides of the, of the discussion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I would say this: I am blessed with having a Committee of highly thoughtful people who bring diverse life experiences and diverse careers, and, of course, diverse views to our work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I wouldn’t have it any other way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, so I would just say, the right—in our discussions the last couple of days, the whole Committee, everybody on the Committee is very supportive of the Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy and what’s in there—very, very broad support, unanimous support for that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everyone sees the, the changes in the underlying economy and sees, in their own way, the need to address those—and including the changes we made to the employment mandate and to inflation so that we’re now at flexible average inflation targeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, there would be—this is—you know, we’re the first major central bank to adopt this framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s no cookbook, and we—you know, this is the first guidance under our new framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, of course there would be a wide range of views, and you would expect that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s actually a healthy thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I welcome that discussion.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would also say this: You September 16, 2020 know, this is all about credibility, and we understand perfectly that we have to earn credibility.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL This, this facility—this, this framework has to—we have to support it with our actions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think today is a very good first step in doing that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is strong, powerful guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is—it ties in very nicely with the Statement of [on] Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We had quite a robust discussion, and there are, there are different ideas on how to do this, but I—that’s just, that’s just the way it is when you have a diverse group of highly thoughtful and effective people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so I’m pleased with where it came out.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Hannah Lang.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: Thanks so much for taking my question.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: I wanted to ask about commercial real estate.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: I, I know you had mentioned before how you weren’t sure if there was a way the Fed could support CRE borrowers.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: But I was just wondering if you had—if you’ve had any other continuing discussions on that and if there’s any potential way that the Fed could step in in that area.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So thank you for that question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we’ve actually spent quite a bit of time on this as Secretary Mnuchin, I think, mentioned the other day.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll say just a couple things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: First, you know, our facilities are essentially always—they have to be, under the law—broad based and not so much targeting any single sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Also, it’s important to remember that CRE, commercial real estate, benefits from several of our existing facilities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the TALF takes commercial mortgage-backed securities and SBA commercial real estate deals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the New York Fed purchases agency CMBSs directly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, I would say, Main Street helps businesses pay their rent, you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re helping real estate, you know, in a number of other ways—commercial real estate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Also, CMBS issuance has resumed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Spreads have tightened on CMBS.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are a couple of issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One is just that commercial properties with CMBS loans often have covenants—uniformly, I think, have covenants that forbid them to take on more debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you have a situation, and you have a situation where, where you—without a legal change or some kind of an innovation that defies discovery so far, you’re—you have a hard time providing mass relief with regard to real estate that’s in, in commercial mortgage-backed securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re still working on it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re still looking.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would say, it may be that further support for commercial real estate will require further action for Congress—from Congress.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: For the last question, we’ll go to Brian Cheung.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Hi, Chairman Powell.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: So it seems like a lot of the new inflation framework is about shaping inflation expectations.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: But the average American who might be watching this might be confused as to why the Fed is overshooting inflation.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: So what’s your explanation to Main Street, to average people what the Fed is trying to do here and what the outcome would be for those on Main Street?

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a very, very important question, and I actually spoke about that in my Jackson Hole remarks a couple weeks ago.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not intuitive to people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is intuitive that, that high inflation is a bad thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s less intuitive that inflation can be too low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the way I would explain it is, is that inflation that’s too low will mean that interest rates are lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s an expectation of future inflation that’s built into every interest rate, right?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And to the extent inflation gets lower and lower and lower, interest rates get lower and lower.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then the Fed will have less room to cut rates to support the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And this isn’t some idle, you know, academic theory.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is what’s happening all over the world.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you, if you look at many, many large jurisdictions around the world, you are seeing that phenomenon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we want inflation to be—we want it to be 2 percent, and we want it to average 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if inflation averages 2 percent, the public will expect that, and that’ll be what’s built into interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s just—that’s all we want.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re not looking to have high inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We just want inflation to average 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that means that, you know, in a downturn, these days, what happens is, inflation, as has happened now—it moves down well below 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that means that we’ve said for, for—we would like to see and we will conduct policies so that inflation moves, for some time, moderately above 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it won’t be—these won’t be large overshoots, and they won’t be permanent but to help anchor inflation expectations at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, yes, it’s, it’s a challenging concept for a lot of people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, nonetheless, the economic importance of it is, is large.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, those are the people we’re serving, and, you know, we serve them best if we can actually achieve average 2 percent inflation, we believe.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why we changed our framework.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
